"The produce of the Gambia at present is principally ground-nuts, wax, and hides. Several years ago gold and ivory used to come from Dentilia and Sego to Yarburtenda, by the roads to the south of the head-waters of Gambia, but tribal wars have closed these roads, and gold now goes overland, via Sego, to North Africa. Yarburtenda is the highest port for trade now on the Gambia. Twenty miles above that place are the rapids of Burmeoonda, which, of course, put a stop to navigation by vessels, but are open for large canoes or lighters, and the river could be worked by these for nearly 200 miles farther up, making Yarburtenda a base depot for the interior trade. This would leave about 400 miles of road to connect the Gambia with the Upper Niger by caravan. At the forks of the Gambia, about ninety miles by water above Yarburtenda, is the town Jellacotta, which is most favourably situated as a centre of trade, and from which both branches of the Upper Gambia could be worked; and the water traffic on the road to Sego could be carried on 100 miles further, by the south-west branch; or, taking the direct land route to Sego, the road goes from Jellacotta to Bady, from there to Badoo, then to Banniseralie, then on to Kamalia, and touches the Upper Niger at Yammina, about twenty miles above Sego. It was across this line of country that Mungo Park travelled. Jellacotta can be reached from Yarburtenda by road across country, distance sixty miles, but, of course, the river is the best mode of transit. Except Timbuctoo, Sego Seguro, the capital of Bamburra, is the most important centre of commerce in North-west Africa. King Amadu is a talented and enlightened prince, and is most anxious to open trade relations with Gambia, but he declines to do so to any extent with Senegal, as he fears the French. He is very rich, and has the largest and best organised army in this part of the continent. In Sego are large and well-built stone houses shops, bazaars, and markets, restaurants, and caravanserais. The trade at present is in the hands of Arabs. A. M. Solleillet, a French traveller, is about to publish an account of his travels, forbear further description on native evidence of the capital of Bamburra.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1879#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.606, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ITALY IN THE RED SEA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Italy, according to the Politische, has, through Count Antonelli, recently concluded three important treaties which are likely to make Assab Bay a real centre of commerce. The caravans from Assab to Shoa, and vice versa, will, in future, be protected by these rulers. The first large caravan has already arrived at Assab Bay, and others are shortly expected.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1883#article-25', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.614, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

result: The observations from the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively underscore the belief in the transformative power of education and the expectation of financial support from influential figures and the African community. The textbook highlights community-driven initiatives, such as the establishment of schools modeled after Tuskegee by African leaders like John Dube, who received land and financial contributions from local supporters, reflecting a belief in education's transformative potential. Influential figures like Booker T. Washington and Marcus Garvey are noted for promoting educational and economic opportunities for Africans. However, the textbook does not specifically emphasize financial support from wealthy Africans for women's education, despite mentioning educational initiatives and the role of women like Charlotte Manye Maxeke in founding schools. In contrast, The African Times articles provide details on donations from notable individuals such as Lord Calthorpe, Sir Fowell Buxton, and Miss Burdett Coutts, as well as organizations like the Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge and the Moravian Brethren, highlighting the involvement of influential figures in educational funding. The articles emphasize the expectation of financial support from wealthy Africans, particularly in raising funds for educational initiatives on the Gold Coast and Cape Coast, appealing to native educated trading friends and wealthy chiefs. The focus on improving educational opportunities for women is evident in efforts to establish schools for African women at Cape Coast and the mention of a female transport corps, underscoring education's transformative potential for women. However, the articles do not explicitly mention financial support from wealthy Africans for women's education, which is a slight deviation from the claim. Overall, both sources illustrate the belief in education's transformative power and the expectation of financial contributions from both influential figures and the African community.

By 1908, Charlotte Manye Maxeke and her spouse had obtained enough money from the Missionary Department to buy land in Transvaal, build a hall (named after Bishop Coppin) and to move the school (now named Wilberforce Institution) to its permanent location at Evaton.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.634, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The social repercussions of colonial rule: the new social structures', 'section_title': 'The main forces of change', 'content': 'Unlike urbanization, western education was brought to Africa by Europe, though not spread by her agencies alone. It is correct to say that the educational revolution in Africa was the work of three interest groups Christian missions, colonial governments and local African initiative, in that order of importance. For the Christian missions the school was a key institution, being the most reliable means for membership recruitment, and for creating self-perpetuating congregations whose members would ensure the survival of Christianity in the event of withdrawal by the white missionaries. Education and evangelization were so closely linked that for many parts of Africa the pitching of the missionary tent was synonymous with the establishment of a school. Among the Nguni the opening of a school is said to have preceded the opening of a church in all cases. 4
The colonial administrations, on their part, hoped through the school to raise the low-grade personnel they needed for staffing the bottom echelons of the colonial bureaucracy, to create such conditions - political, economic, social and moral - as would enable Europe to exploit as fully as possible what were regarded as the hitherto insufficiently tapped resources of Africa. To this end not only did colonial administrations erect and run essentially lay schools, they also supported the educational efforts of the missions by means of subventions. Furthermore, the political settle› ments they effected enabled the missions to penetrate the heart of the continent without fearing for the safety of their agents. The government lay schools were particularly important for the spread of western education in many Islamized parts of Africa where it was feared that unrestrained missionary activity would provoke violent reaction from Muslims.
With regard to local initiative, it is noteworthy that even before the onset of colonial rule, the rulers of Egypt and of the states of the Maghrib had introduced western education into their countries as part of an effort to bridge the technological gap between their societies and Europe. In black Africa local initiative also played some part in spreading education. Soon, then, let us hope that the schools will be planted in Cape Coast Castle, and that girls and women shall press into them for the benefits of instruction they will afford. It must be a labour of faith as well as of love. "Whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap." Nothing yields a more plentiful harvest than seed sown for eternity, such as help and prayers that may be given to raise our needy and less advanced brethren and sisters in the scale of true Christianity, civilization, usefulness, and industry.'}, {'id': 4113, 'article_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': '11-04-1880', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1881#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_01_1881', 'content': 'I hope, Sir, some abler pen than mine will take up this subject, and give it that treatment which its paramount importance justly deserves; and more than this, I would fain hope that all your able pleadings will result in some substantial aid being afforded from head-quarters to the cause of education on the Coast.

Again thanking you, Mr. Editor, for all your noble efforts on behalf of our country, and wishing you every good wish, I remain, yours, &c.,'}, {'id': 6090, 'article_title': '"Higher Education" for West Africans', 'full_section_title': '"Higher Education" for West Africans', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_05_1891#article-3', 'issue_date': '04_05_1891', 'content': 'We are pleased to learn that the subject of Higher Education is now engaging the attention of the good people on the West Coast; and we learn from a recent issue of the Lagos Times that a meeting was lately convened at the residence of Mr. Otonba Payne, Chief Registrar and Taxing Master of the Supreme Court, when Captain J. P. L. Davies, J.P., was elected President, and J. S. Leigh, Esq., Vice-President of a Committee to secure the development of Higher Education in Lagos. We are informed that the scheme which found most favour among those who are chiefly interested in this important subject, was to float a Limited Company, consisting of 2,000 Shares of £1 each, which would secure a sum amply sufficient to make a beginning in this most desirable object. Many of our readers, we doubt not, will be pleased to support such a highly patriotic endeavour, especially remembering the great risk which the native youth have to run if sent for their education to such a cold and uncertain climate as England.'}]

[{'document_title': "Mrs. Moseley's Cape Coast School", 'section_title': '', 'content': "My dear Mr. Fitzgerald,—Feeling that just at this juncture in my efforts for my dear African friends in Cape Coast some assistance from you would prove very valuable, will you kindly bestow upon my proposed work a little further co-operation, and say a few words on its behalf in the columns of the *African Times;* and manifesting as you have long done, and are still doing, such cordial and true interest in the improvement and amelioration of the poor benighted African natives, and earnest desire for their advancement in Christian and industrial civilization, I feel that in your hands and kind pleading I am leaving the cause with some real hope, under God's blessing, of ultimate success. I would just briefly state that in addition to Scriptural instruction in the truths of God's Holy Word, I am so anxious to secure for the poor African women and children instruction also in different branches of industrial knowledge, to render them in time better wives and mothers, and to create in them that legitimate ambition for home and domestic improvement and industry, which would go hand in hand with their moral and social elevation, and render them, I trust, please God, a truly happy, Christian, and prosperous population. Having for a short time sojourned amongst them, I have witnessed their great need in this respect; and have long mourned over my own individual inability in not being able to have sent them ere this the efficient means for establishing an institution of the character I have described to meet this great necessity. However, I do now trust, by the joint kindly and liberal help of English Christian hearts, we shall accomplish this important object, please God, for these poor African women and their little ones; as I cannot but feel that the aid and sympathy already elicited for this desired work is an earnest of greater and more effectual means to accomplish it ultimately. A Christian lady has promised me articles in fancy and useful work to the amount of 100l. if I can dispose of them, and which I trust to do in the spring; and any further contributions to increase this collection will be, too, of great help to our fund, if any persons who are not able to give money would kindly send us a little assistance in this form. Leaving your more powerful pen to plead all the rest for my Cape Coast friends, and with grateful thanks for your valuable co-operation, believe me, dear Mr. Fitzgerald, yours truly obliged,", 'last_edit_date': '1865-12-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1865#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.623, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Female Education at Cape Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Donations and subscriptions, however small, are earnestly solicited from the Christian and benevolent public, on behalf of a school for the spiritual and industrial instruction of the native converts and population at Cape Coast Castle, an institution the most highly calculated to raise and ameliorate the religious and social condition of the poor benighted Africans, by teaching them

* The first transport corps for the supply of the troops on the Ashantee frontier, ninety miles from Cape Coast, with provisions and military stores, was a female one!', 'last_edit_date': '1864-08-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1864#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.634, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'CHRISTIAN EDUCATION FOR AND IN AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In answer to an invitation from Samuel Gurney, Esq., to meet Mr. Edward S. Morris, of Philadelphia and Liberia, a meeting was held at Devonshire House, London, April 21st, 1879, when the following resolution was unanimously passed: "That the thanks of this meeting be given to Mr. Morris, for his interesting and encouraging statement on the condition and prospects of Liberia; that we fully agree with him as to the crying necessity for Christian schools in Africa, and earnestly desire that every necessary means may be given him to make his estate (800 acres) in Liberia a nursery of education, industrial as well as literary—especially for the sons of native chiefs, and the future kings of Africa." Mr. Morris was recommended to Samuel Gurney, Esq. by Mr. Welsh, the United States Minister in London, in terms which we feel compelled to quote: "Mr. Morris has thrown an enthusiastic energy into the work he has entered upon, which gives the strongest promise of success. His earnest desire is for the Christian education of the sons of the savage chiefs who border on Liberia. They are to be the future rulers of Africa. This is to be his life-work; and his instruments will be schools for the purpose established in Liberia. In such a cause he cannot fail to have the support of many good people." Mr. Morris has secured an estate of 800 acres in Liberia, where he is about to erect his college, in which he proposes to educate the sons of native kings and chiefs. His admirable plan is to make them at the same time educated men, Christians, and practical coffee planters and general agriculturists. This is surely a work fraught with well-grounded hopes of at present incalculable good to Africa; and as such, Mr. Morris, who seems to us to be peculiarly fitted for it, has our warmest desires and earnest prayers for a full measure of success. Mr. T. A. Denny, of London, has promised 100l. of the 1,000l. required by Mr. Morris, who, in his letter to Joseph Gurney Barclay, Esq., and George Williams, Esq.,—well-known in London business circles—who have accepted the office of Treasurers for the funds which Mr. Morris hopes to collect while in England, says: "When the school-house shall have been built, the teacher engaged and at his post of duty, and the boys in their seats, THEN will I commence to draw on the funds deposited, and placed in your hands as Treasurers."', 'last_edit_date': '1879-04-21', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1879#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.617, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Too much praise cannot be given you for your unwearied and long-continued efforts on behalf of poor Africa and her unfortunate sons. The lively interest and heartfelt sympathy you have always manifested in the work of Africa's regeneration and advancement seems ever to be increasing with the onward march of time, and it is to be hoped that such zealous and benevolent efforts will be crowned with abundant success.

Your remarks on the subject of Education in your last two issues, and the convincing arguments you advanced to recommend the subject to the notice of the "higher powers," have been read by not a few here with feelings of deep gratitude and satisfaction. It is greatly to be hoped that such an earnest appeal will not be suffered to pass by unheard. It is gratifying to state that the Accra Church of England High-class School has been fairly established and set in proper working order, and since its establishment the number of its pupils has been steadily on the increase. If, as stated in my previous correspondence, such a school as the High-class School be amply and efficiently supported, it will prove a great boon to the place. That the educational work that is thus being inaugurated here needs such support as you have pleaded for will be evident from the fact that it has not been undertaken by the Church Missionary Society, as your remarks would seem to indicate, but by the sole efforts of some of the native residents of this place, who, sensible of the great educational wants of the community, have requested the Bishop of Sierra Leone to aid them in the establishment here of the Church of England with a properly-organized school; and the kind-hearted prelate, ever ready to lend a helping hand to every very good work, promised to aid their efforts in the undertaking. From this it will be seen that such needful help as you have advocated is a *sine qua non* in the proper development of education in this place; and should it be afforded, an efficient staff of competent teachers will be secured, and high-class schools, grammar schools, collegiate schools, and other seminaries of learning will be established along this Coast, which will undoubtedly be productive of unspeakable benefit to the country at large. This, Mr. Editor, in my humble opinion, will be the only panacea for the effectual eradication of the moral, social, and intellectual evil under which "the land is groaning."

The hope of this country's elevation seems to me to be in the rising and future generations, in the proper development of their intellectual faculties, and the instilment into their minds of the "sweets" of education. Without this, there will be but small encouragement to hope for the fulfilment of the oft-repeated prophecy of "Africa shall rise."', 'last_edit_date': '1880-11-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1881#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.07, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE ACTION OF THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Africa, anything beyond the mere egotism of surface philanthropy, it will find fresh support. If it ever perish for want of it, while, as now, faithful in its mission, disgrace to those who shall have allowed it to perish. And here we must say one word to the educated Africans of the West Coast. They have recognised, and are recognising, by their subscriptions to this paper, the importance to them of the African Times. But they have not as yet done anything for the support of The Society whose influence makes that journal a power. In future every subscription will be published in this paper. Every educated and commercial African ought to feel that this society is his. The name of every one ought to be found year by year in the list of its annual subscribers. There are hundreds who can afford their one or two guineas a-year. It is only thus they can show that they recognise the important efforts of this society for them and for their race and country; thus only they can show that they are alive to the vast benefits of the civilization of which they have themselves become partakers. It was for this that we hailed with peculiar satisfaction the annual subscription of the Rev. Mr. Robbin, Colonial Chaplain at the Gambia, as announced in our last. His worthy and honoured name stands first on the list of our African subscribers. We hope, for the credit of the educated Africans, that it is but the first of hundreds. We most earnestly desire to see that fund completed. Mrs. Moseley ought to leave England in October on her work of love and mercy. Would that some of our friends whom God has abundantly blessed would come forward with the really small amount now wanting to make up the required sum!', 'last_edit_date': '1867-08-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1867#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICA AND THE JUBILEE FUND OF THE WESLEYAN MISSIONARY SOCIETY', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Wesleyan Missionary Society have raised a large Jubilee Fund at Leeds, and other towns. We are glad to see that a prominent place is given to Africa and her children in the contemplated disposal of it. The following is from the monthly organ of the Society: "It was deeply felt by the Committee that the hope for the evangelization of Africa must mainly rest on the employment of a native agency. The difficulties of the African languages form a barrier to the free labour of English missionaries among the African nations, and the climate of large portions of that vast continent is very unfavourable to European health and life. At the same time, on every mission in Western and in Southern Africa there have been found native converts who have been deemed suitable to be employed as teachers among their countrymen. Some of these have been honoured of God with great success. It is desired that means may be provided for the training and employment of a much larger number of native African agents; and that at important centres, hereafter to be selected, schools or institutions should be formed for that purpose, to be commenced and sustained by an appropriation from the Jubilee Fund. In contemplation of the vastness of the field of labour in Africa it will be admitted that a large amount may with propriety be consecrated to this service.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.617, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LIBERIA COLLEGE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are glad to see that higher education is making progress in Liberia. The following from the *Observer*, extracted from a "Circular," is of interest, and appeals strongly to the friends of Africa:—

"It is now proposed to take a new departure. It is expected that students will avail themselves of the advantages of the college not only from all parts of the Republic, but from other settlements along the coast, and from the tribes in the interior. In respect to funds, the trustees feel that in view of the increased work which lies before them, they will urgently need far larger pecuniary assistance than the institution has yet had. Increased endowments are necessary to enable the institution to hold its position and fulfil its functions as a college. It is the object of the trustees to encourage and assist needy boys, who give promise of usefulness, especially from among the aborigines, to obtain a liberal education. To this end they earnestly solicit the establishment of permanent scholarships. Professorships of Ancient Languages and Mathematics are provided for. There is urgent need now for endowments of Professorships in the departments of the Moral and Physical Sciences, of Jurisprudence, and of Arabic and the Native vernaculars. . . . No provision is at present made for boarding the students in the college building; but board may be had in respectable families in the neighbourhood of the College, at prices varying from ten to twelve dollars, or from 2l. to 2l. 10s. per month. The charges for one year, for students from abroad, including all expenses, will vary from 150 to 200 dols., or from 30l. to 40l. sterling, according to the disposition of the students."', 'last_edit_date': '1881-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1881#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.626, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'But besides the establishment of elementary schools, it is desirable for the Government to aid in the establishment of superior colleges for young men and young women in its most advanced West African settlement, Sierra Leone. There is a demand for this; and since the Government has rendered very little help to educational work, it is right for us to expect that it would take up such a work earnestly. The people unaided are unable to provide themselves with such establishments. The practice has been adopted of sending young men and young women to England for education, but it is a very expensive one and is attended with a great risk, and comparatively very few persons can use it. The success that has attended it is one of a doubtful character. Some have returned home with enfeebled constitutions. English teachers have not generally been able to imbue the minds of their African scholars with patriotism, and a sense of their obligations and responsibility to their country. There has been too much of being wrapt up in self. Expensiveness and the fear of their succumbing to the effects of a foreign and trying climate have often necessitated a short stay, and placed them at a disadvantage. Colleges such as I have spoken of will be a boon to the whole Coast, and be hailed with gladness; and if, after successful residence in them, visits are made to England for a finishing, much good will, I think, be done thereby.

In this matter, as in that of elementary schools for the Gold Coast, the Government will find it most helpful to ask the aid and co-operation of the Church Missionary Society, that has already a very good foundation to work upon. I would not ask that any burden be laid upon British taxpayers; local funds should be economized for this work, and a combination of local Government efforts would remove much of the pecuniary difficulty that may be raised in the matter of superior colleges.—I am, dear Sir, yours truly,', 'last_edit_date': '1875-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1875#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.624, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'When writing last month on the all-important subject of the future spread of Christian civilization in West Africa, we pointed out that educated natives, more or less under the influence of Christian faith, more or less imbued with Christian principles, more or less governed by Christian precepts, are and will be indispensable as a vanguard of the great army of civilization that must be projected upon the ignorant barbarism of heathen Africa whenever the means for such projection shall be arranged. We go further than this, and equally maintain that not only the vanguard of the army of civilization must necessarily consist of educated Africans, but that the army itself must be chiefly composed of them. With this conviction rooted in our mind, the question of education in West Africa has for many years past greatly occupied our attention. The end in view being so great, and of so vast importance primarily to Africa, and secondarily to the whole civilized world, it is natural we should have asked ourself whether the means of education at present employed are adequate for the purpose; and if not, how and by whom those means are to be made so. We have already adverted to the unselfish efforts of the religious societies of Great Britain (and in the case of Liberia, of those of the United States of America) in diffusing among the natives the great blessing of education. The efforts of the Missionary Societies, and more especially of the Church Missionary Society, have been unremitting and gradually increasing in scope and efficiency, until they would seem at last to have culminated in the affiliation of their Fomah Bay College at Sierra Leone to the University of Durham, whereby degrees may be obtained by Africans who have never left their native land. By these efforts of Missionary Societies, the Church of England and the Wesleyan Methodist, all who can boast of any degree of education in West Africa have been rescued from heathen ignorance, and prepared more or less, for civilized usefulness. It was, perhaps, well and unavoidable, though we are far from saying or thinking that it was so, that so all-important a work, if Africa is ever to be rescued from heathen degradation, should have been hitherto left in the hands of the Missionary Societies. But that it ought any longer to be so left, we most emphatically deny. Under those noble efforts of the Missionary Societies, combined with constantly increasing facilities for commerce which steam navigation has supplied, the condition of the British settlements has undergone so great a change, that a continued dependence on missionary effort for the education of the people will, if persisted in, be a gross injustice and disgrace on the part of the British Government. This is so patent that we feel convinced it is only necessary the subject should be urged upon their attention to induce such action on their part as shall wipe away the reproach that now justly attaches to them, and relieve the Missionary Societies from a charge to which their funds, so urgently required for the propagation of Christian truth in other localities in the great heathen world, ought not to be any longer subject. Education ought to be now organized and diffused in and from the British settlements by and at the charge of the local revenues. The inadequacy of means, which as regards the Gold Coast, for instance, might have been pleaded some ten or twelve years ago, when the public revenue there did not exceed annually the sum of seven or eight thousand pounds, can no longer be urged now that the revenue has attained the comparatively magnificent amount of one hundred thousand pounds a year. A similar comparative increase has been experienced at Lagos; and if the revenues of Sierra Leone and the Gambia have not advanced in the same ratio, they are still sufficient, if properly administered, to meet the great and urgent want of public education, under the organization and auspices of the State. A State education is what we now claim for West Africa, and in especial for the Gold Coast and Lagos. A systematic and adequate commencement of it ought not to be any longer delayed. A Liberal Government in Great Britain cannot surely any longer deny to the people of West Africa that of which they have been such earnest promoters, both individually and collectively, at home. It can scarcely be necessary to remind the Earl of Kimberley that, as Crown Colonies, those settlements are altogether dependent upon an initiative from Downing-street; that themselves, the people, even if they felt the need, can do nothing; that the expenditure of the public revenue is entirely at the command of the Secretary of State for the Colonies; and that it now rests with him either to aid in or retard the Christian civilization of West Africa, which cannot progress without a more general diffusion of education than can or ought to be expected from the Missionary Societies of Great Britain. While, however, we are prepared to maintain that it is now the duty of Government to undertake the work of the education of the people, both elementary and higher, in all the West African settlements, we shall confine ourselves more especially at this time to the claims and needs of the Gold Coast and Lagos. The influence that may be diffused from these British settlements in the great work of the civilization of Africa would be immense, and justly entitles them to our especial consideration as regards public education in West Africa. It is from Lagos that the work of civilization must proceed to the moral conquest of the whole of those extensive territories that are bounded by the River Niger, and of that blood-stained kingdom of Dahomey, whose sanguinary customs continue, though of late but little spoken of, to outrage humanity, and exhibit the worst features of ignorant heathen barbarism. In considering the question of State education in Lagos, it is incumbent on the British Government to take into consideration that the public revenue of that portion of the Gold Coast Colony is derived entirely from traffic in the produce of those interior countries; that the spread of civilization increases production; and that therefore, while on the one hand it is imperatively their duty, it is not less their interest, as rulers of this Crown settlement, to devote a portion of that revenue to constitute Lagos a focus of light from Britain, to be diffused throughout the Egba and Yoruba countries, and the territories of their unquiet neighbour, Dahomey. The presence of Great Britain on the coasts of these countries of West Africa, after her own renunciation and denunciation of the infamous and horrible foreign slave-trade, was justified by her presence there being absolutely necessary for securing the final annihilation of that traffic, and remedying in some degree, by the security she gave and the repression she exercised, the fearful results that had been produced there by it, and the outrages on humanity perpetrated at the behests of sanguinary superstitions, which had been made through successive ages its active agents and accomplices. Under her ægis a new condition of things has gradually arisen; and although—such is the tenacity of evil—her presence could not even yet be dispensed with as regards the repression of slave-trading propensities, this repression ought now to be regarded as a secondary, and the spread of civilization the primary, justification of her continued rule. Those who have known this journal during the past twenty years cannot need to be reminded that we have ever laid it down as an axiom that a basis of British power on the Coast is indispensable to the success of missionary enterprise and the progress of civilization in Africa. The natives have become so debased by superstition during ages upon ages of heathen darkness, that they are incapable of believing in anything that does not come to them accompanied by evidences of power. They have such evidence at Lagos; they have it within the mainland territories of the Gold Coast Colony. That evidence will suffice to insure the gradual acceptance of civilization when once the interior populations, as well as those in the Coast towns,', 'last_edit_date': '1880-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1880#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.633, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'West Coast Government', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'portance, the presence of a continually increasing number of African girls educated in some of the best schools in England. Populations among which there is a large growing section of such elements cannot for ever be treated as ignorant barbarians or as children. Education gives rights to some voice in the shaping of the national destinies, and primarily, in the management of local institutions and progress. We appeal on their behalf to the Home Government that this important matter may be taken into serious and unprejudiced consideration. Power is so dear to the hearts of men, and prejudices have so much influence in human decisions, that West Coast Governors and European Executive officers, when consulted by the Secretary of State, will most likely say they, the educated natives, are not fitted for anything but absolute dependence; but the day will come, and we ask that it may now come, when Councils more just and wise shall prevail in Downing Street, and educated West Africa will receive that consideration to which it has now become entitled.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1881#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.634, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRIBES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At a meeting of the Royal Colonial Institute, held lately in the Grosvenor Gallery Library, New Bond-street, a paper was read by Mr. William Greswell, M.A., on "The Education of the South African Tribes." The lecturer said: The future of South Africa was much bound up with this question of administration, and especially the educational part of it. A proper education meant an assimilation of the coloured man to the ideal of the white man, with regard to habits of mind and of thought. The question of education was visibly affected by political disturbances. With regard to the general question, which was viewed in many different ways by white people both in the colony and at home, he said the great desideratum of the hour in South Africa was to raise the discussion of important matters beyond the atmosphere of party. Nothing had so much injured the native as the custom of using him for the purpose of a party cry. Premising that he should confine himself principally to the state of affairs in the Cape Colony, the Lecturer said he should show that there had existed and did still exist in that colony a State scheme for the instruction of the natives in nearly everything they might require to know, whether it was to shoe a horse, make a wheel, or learn Greek. As he had himself endeavoured to instruct the Caffre in the Greek declensions, in his capacity as Government Lecturer in the colony, he might say that the loftiness and catholicity of the scheme had come home to him. Remarking upon the difficulties in the way of applying such a scheme in a sparsely-peopled savage country like South Africa, he said the number of white colonists at the Cape was about equal to the population of Leeds, and these had to legislate for the reclamation of more than a million blacks, who were scattered over an immense tract. Other difficulties lay in the unequal social developments among the black people, in the bi-lingual character of the white population, and in the want of unanimity on the part of the white colonists as to the proper lines upon which native education ought to go. To bring under one system of State education men of different religious views, hard though it might be, was an easy task for the political legislator compared with that encountered in an attempt to group under one plan men so intellectually and, if he might use the term, spiritually distinct as the European and the African aboriginal races. The difference between the races was, practically speaking, one absolutely of kind, not of degree. Undeterred by difficulties, legislators at the Cape had boldly grappled with the question, and they had established a complete educational ladder, with the kraal schools at the bottom and the university at the top. After going with some detail into the working of the scheme in that colony, and suggesting some possible improvements in the system, he remarked that though philanthropy in theory, in practice it was unphilosophic. A cardinal fact was ignored—the generic difference between the European and the Caffre. The principle of heredity was ignored. He was inclined to believe that the Caffre would be influenced by a simple and rather an autocratic system. hh: The advancement and prosperity of Africa are heavily reliant on integrating practical and technical education into traditional schooling to foster economic self-sufficiency, social improvement, and conflict resolution.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles strongly support the claim that Africa's advancement and prosperity are heavily reliant on integrating practical and technical education into traditional schooling. The textbook highlights the historical context, noting that American education, particularly industrial or vocational training, was embraced by colonial entrepreneurs and government officials for its potential to drive economic development and produce well-trained artisans, aligning with the claim that practical education fosters economic self-sufficiency. It also points out that the neglect of technical and industrial education contributed to social tensions and civil wars, suggesting its role in conflict resolution. Figures like Booker T. Washington and Marcus Garvey emphasized technical education for economic opportunities and social improvement, although the uneven distribution of educational facilities and colonial focus on liberal and clerical training posed challenges to implementing such reforms. Similarly, The African Times articles underscore the importance of technical education in fostering economic self-sufficiency, highlighting the need for skilled labor in trades like carpentry, masonry, and blacksmithing to reduce reliance on foreign mechanics. The articles also suggest that practical education can lead to social improvement by equipping individuals with skills to transform their communities, as seen in proposals for agricultural training. Furthermore, they link technical education to conflict resolution, proposing that trade and agriculture development can mitigate war and feuds, particularly with the Ashantee. However, challenges such as lack of government support and reliance on missionary societies to fill educational gaps are noted, underscoring the necessity of integrating practical education into traditional schooling. Together, these sources provide a comprehensive view of the critical role of practical and technical education in Africa's development, while also acknowledging historical and contemporary barriers to achieving this integration.

[{'id': 453, 'article_title': 'AFRICA AND HER EVANGELIZATION', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICA AND HER EVANGELIZATION', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1864#article-17', 'issue_date': '23_09_1864', 'content': "It is difficult to eradicate the old habits acquired by age. Their very religion proves not to be at all times an entire conversion, for a lurking regard for their old grugrus and fetishes too frequently shows an uncertainty in the religion they have newly adopted. If in religion this difficulty is found, so in their moral and social culture it must equally, nay, more, prevail. But the young, the young can surely be trained in a way to become useful to their fellow-creatures, and cultivators instead of incumbrances of the social soil.

It has struck me more than once that an anomaly exists, taken advantage of to his own detriment by the black man, and proving a fruitful source of hindrance to the white. *Trade, trade, trade,* in a limited and exceptional view, is the absorbing idea of the black man's mind. If the old man himself can't trade, he will try to do it by and through his children; and hence the cause of continual complaint that children are early removed from school when they were but beginning to learn, and too young to be confirmed in the principles of their moral training.

These difficulties have been often started, but has any remedy been hitherto suggested? If it has, where is it now in operation, and what is its result? Is the complaint removed? If so, why is it that one hears of these difficulties still existing, and proving an almost insurmountable barrier to further progress.

But I respectfully submit that the remedy is as simple, and as clear as simple. The body, or the moral culture of the mind that guides it, must be adapted to its future life. The early training of the child for the cultivation of the soil, where the soil has to be cultivated and subjected to the use of man, must consist not only in the teaching, but in the showing to the child what, when, and how such may be done. Schools might have portions of ground given to them for purposes of illustration; and a profit, by the working of the children, might accrue to the school, and *be shared in by the children also.* Arts and manufactures might gradually be introduced; an interest, by practical illustration, might be thrown into the subject of study or employment; and as the child might largely share the gain, the parents would be benefited, and the child to the man instructed. Thenceforth the man, anxious to show his skill, to settle comfortably in life, and make provision for the future, would be seen to convert a waste land to a farm, a hut into a comfortable house, a wilderness to a paradise and a home."}, {'id': 946, 'article_title': 'Proposed Sending of Young Africans to England "To Learn Mechanical Arts and Legal Practice."', 'full_section_title': 'Proposed Sending of Young Africans to England "To Learn Mechanical Arts and Legal Practice."', 'last_edit_date': '10-23-1866', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1866#article-13', 'issue_date': '23_10_1866', 'content': 'Dismissing, therefore, this part of the proposal without further remark at present, we come to that which refers to mechanical arts. given as regards advantage to Africa and Africans, to the proposal of Dr. Africanus Horton over that of Governor-General Blackall. W. A. ROSS ON CAPE COAST AFFAIRS.', 'full_section_title': 'MR. W. A. ROSS ON CAPE COAST AFFAIRS.', 'last_edit_date': '12-01-1868', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1868#article-15', 'issue_date': '23_12_1868', 'content': 'By the wretched personal recriminations of its official staff, by its maladministration of the law, by its incapacity to glance beyond the range of the passing hour, the Government at Cape Coast has gathered a hornet's nest round its head; but, while that is doubtless so, I believe that the Home Government has not an iota of reason to be proud of the character of its conduct in the alleviation of the helplessness and the penury of the settlements. If the Government at Cape Coast should not, then, be able to relieve itself from the charge of fostering periodical collisions—or periodical menaces of collision—with Ashantee by its unpardonable remissness in the observance of common urbanity, common prudence, or common statecraft, the Home Government cannot be held less venial in the part which it has indirectly played in causing that sort of local spasm and turmoil which idle hands and tongues can always provoke. I contend that the development of trade is the surest cure for war; and I contend that the Home Government has not done enough for the development of the trade of the settlements. It has been answered by the Home Government that undertakings which are commercial should be committed to the assiduity and skill of persons who are devoted to the pursuit of commerce; but I would fain suggest that there are seasons and places when and where the duty is incumbent on the parent state to aid and encourage the rational enterprise of individuals. The Government at Cape Coast has not introduced substantial measures of reform, because it has not had the funds which were sufficient for a purpose so needful. Shaking off the evils of apathy and relinquishing the mere fugitive profits of pedlars, the merchants might have helped the Government at Cape Coast in a career of utility. But whether the shortcomings of the Government at Cape Coast were inevitable, or whether the listlessness and avarice of the merchants could be regarded as censurable, no stable, tangible benefits can spring out of our residence on the Gold Coast, and no permanent safeguards can be reared against "panyarring" and other barbarous acts of retaliation which constantly incite to feuds with Ashantee, unless the African shall be tutored in the rudiments of an acquaintance with our civil life, unless the existence of such efficient ministers of good will—such noble twins of charity and wealth—as trade and agriculture shall be avowed, and unless schools for technical learning shall be rightly and widely promoted.'}, {'id': 1945, 'article_title': "Primitive Methodist Society's Work at Fernando Po", 'full_section_title': "Primitive Methodist Society's Work at Fernando Po", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1870#article-7', 'issue_date': '23_12_1870', 'content': "Dear Mr. Editor,—To convince you and the Christian public in general in England of the importance of a good and efficient school to be maintained by any society who sends their missionaries to this Coast, let me give a few facts. One is now on his way to England on account of the illness of his wife, and only one now remains on the station; perhaps he may be forced to quit as the other did. This we hope not. Is it not, then, absolutely necessary for every Christian mission to maintain an efficient school at all their respective stations out here? Mr. Editor, I really believe you will fully coincide with me. Here is a mission just established—one of the agents sent out forced to quit his post. Should a proper and efficient school be maintained, a proper assistant can be easily procured to supply the vacancy in any similar case. Through you, my dear Mr. Editor, I beg to impress on the Primitive Methodist Society in London that they have done well indeed in supplying this island with two of their excellent ministers (now only one, as the other has already quitted the station, owing to domestic affliction), and that they would do still better in maintaining a good and efficient school on the island. This would be a very life indeed to their African mission, and without this it will be quite impossible for them to succeed to any extent. Let a proper schoolmaster be selected from their academy; he must be an unmarried man, as it is quite the fact, as always reported that the climate of Africa does not agree with the European ladies. This is emphatically the truth, therefore it would be of no use sending married men to come and labour here; it would be merely an eventual waste of lives and money. Let this master be well paid for his services—the money so well spent will confer a great boon on the island and on the generation unborn. If the said Society could afford to pay the present negro teacher the sum of eighty pounds a-year, inefficient as he is, merely to teach reading and spelling, surely the Society would not deem it too expensive to have a competent master appointed and well paid, while the present teacher's wages will be quite sufficient to procure valuable assistants to the master of the school from the Wesleyan or Church of England Colleges at Sierra Leone. The present Africans, Mr. Editor, are fully determined to take their rank if possible among the civilised nations, but without proper training this would be quite impossible. Reading and spelling would not suffice as the requirements of Africans in the nineteenth century. We know a little about what is taught by preaching, as some of the preachers said we are thankful for the little, and we know that if this leads to holy lives and faith in Christ we have ample assurance of heaven.—Yours,"}, {'id': 3028, 'article_title': 'High-class Education in Lagos, for Lagos and the Gold Coast', 'full_section_title': 'High-class Education in Lagos, for Lagos and the Gold Coast', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1876#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_01_1876', 'content': 'We had heard rumours that the Wesleyan Missionary Society intended to establish a high school at Cape Coast and another at Lagos. No one can feel a deeper interest than we do in the spread of education on the West Coast of Africa, and we have not given up our hopes of being ere long instrumental in aiding it. We should have been very sorry had the rumour above mentioned proved to be the voice of a fact. Lagos and the Gold Coast, included now in one colony, are not far distant one from the other, and it would seem to us a great waste of energy to establish and attempt to carry on two high schools so near the one to the other, when one might be made to meet all the necessities of the Fantee and Aku countries in this matter. We are happy, therefore, to be able to state that there is not any such intention on the part of the Wesleyan Missionary Society, who will concentrate all their energies in this direction on one such school at Lagos. We understand that liberal arrangements have been made by this energetic Society for establishing the Lagos School and making it an efficient one. Native catechists and school teachers are much wanted, and it is only through such schools that the want can be supplied. It is not creditable to the Government that they do so little toward providing for public education out of the ample revenues of the Gold Coast Colony. Education must now be the first great element of development and progress there. All that can be done without it has been done. Commerce has stimulated production to a certain extent, by offering to the ignorant natives the means for supplying certain physical wants and gratifying the lower class of desires; but it is education alone that will create the larger range of wants and...

The higher class of desires, the demands of which will be irresistible incentives to more intelligent industry and more sustained exertion. To give this education is a duty that does not properly belong to Missionary Societies, who ought not to be expected to do more than train those whom they require for missionary work. But missionary work cannot be carried on in West Africa without imparting secular knowledge to the people; and since the Government neglect their duty in this respect, the Missionary Societies have no alternative but to undertake it or abandon their work altogether. It cannot therefore be a matter for surprise that they take upon themselves the task of imparting that knowledge. The establishment of a high school at Lagos will meet a great and pressing want; and we hope it will prove as beneficial as the zealous Committee of the Wesleyan Missionary Society have been encouraged to expect.'}, {'id': 4113, 'article_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': '11-04-1880', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1881#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_01_1881', 'content': 'Sir,—Too much praise cannot be given you for your unwearied and long-continued efforts on behalf of poor Africa and her unfortunate sons. The lively interest and heartfelt sympathy you have always manifested in the work of Africa's regeneration and advancement seems ever to be increasing with the onward march of time, and it is to be hoped that such zealous and benevolent efforts will be crowned with abundant success.

Your remarks on the subject of Education in your last two issues, and the convincing arguments you advanced to recommend the subject to the notice of the "higher powers," have been read by not a few here with feelings of deep gratitude and satisfaction. It is greatly to be hoped that such an earnest appeal will not be suffered to pass by unheard. It is gratifying to state that the Accra Church of England High-class School has been fairly established and set in proper working order, and since its establishment the number of its pupils has been steadily on the increase. If, as stated in my previous correspondence, such a school as the High-class School be amply and efficiently supported, it will prove a great boon to the place. That the educational work that is thus being inaugurated here needs such support as you have pleaded for will be evident from the fact that it has not been undertaken by the Church Missionary Society, as your remarks would seem to indicate, but by the sole efforts of some of the native residents of this place, who, sensible of the great educational wants of the community, have requested the Bishop of Sierra Leone to aid them in the establishment here of the Church of England with a properly-organized school; and the kind-hearted prelate, ever ready to lend a helping hand to every very good work, promised to aid their efforts in the undertaking. From this it will be seen that such needful help as you have advocated is a *sine qua non* in the proper development of education in this place; and should it be afforded, an efficient staff of competent teachers will be secured, and high-class schools, grammar schools, collegiate schools, and other seminaries of learning will be established along this Coast, which will undoubtedly be productive of unspeakable benefit to the country at large. This, Mr. Editor, in my humble opinion, will be the only panacea for the effectual eradication of the moral, social, and intellectual evil under which "the land is groaning."

The hope of this country's elevation seems to me to be in the rising and future generations, in the proper development of their intellectual faculties, and the instilment into their minds of the "sweets" of education. Without this, there will be but small encouragement to hope for the fulfilment of the oft-repeated prophecy of "Africa shall rise."'}, {'id': 5170, 'article_title': 'TRADE IN BRITISH WEST AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'TRADE IN BRITISH WEST AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_08_1885', 'content': '1. This trade, increasing as it does year by year in its lucrative character, is capable of vast improvement in the settlements themselves, at the trading stations and in the interior. The British possessions on the coast must take care to develop at home, if they would make their towns centres for increased traffic beyond their limits. The roads inland must become something more than mere paths. There ought to be the commencement of River Conservancy Boards on a small scale, in order that the sand-bars, snags, and freshets of the Volta and the Prah should cease to be hindrances to the working of the coal fields on the former, and to ordinary commerce on the latter. Far more gold could be produced from the Gold Coast and Ashanti if proper modes of working were adopted. A railroad has been projected at Cape Coast Town, and such an undertaking, if consisting of a single line of rails only, either along the coast or towards the interior, would do much to abase barbaric power in Ashanti and Dahomi. The traffic in spirits, so fraught with evil to natives everywhere, ought to be forbidden by Act of the Imperial Parliament, the cargo to be seized and destroyed, and the owners subjected to a heavy fine. And is it not time for the construction of docks at practicable spots, and for taking precautions against the recurrence of the fires which devastate Freetown and Lagos so frequently? As there are few masons, carpenters, wheelwrights, and painters to be found on the coast, ought not an industrial school to be added to the existing educational establishments for the purpose of teaching those trades? These enterprises, pretentious as they may seem when proposed in connexion with communities so young in civilization as the West African negro settlements, are nevertheless certainly feasible, if the educated Africans will only put their own shoulders to the wheel. One of their own number, Dr. Africanus Horton, was the first to propose most of them several years ago in an address to the African Aid Society, and it is time now that public and private attention should be given to his suggestions.'}, {'id': 5996, 'article_title': "The Queen's Speech at the Prorogation of Parliament", 'full_section_title': "The Queen's Speech at the Prorogation of Parliament", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1890#article-0', 'issue_date': '01_09_1890', 'content': 'I am rejoiced to observe that effective steps have been taken by you for the promotion of primary, intermediate, and technical education.

I trust that the measures which you have passed for the extensive reconstruction of barracks will secure the health and increase the efficiency of my soldiers. I commend you earnestly to the care and blessing of Almighty God.

After the conclusion of this Speech, Parliament was formally prorogued by Royal Commission till Saturday, Oct. 25.'}, {'id': 6483, 'article_title': '"Technical Education" in West Africa', 'full_section_title': '"Technical Education" in West Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1894#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_08_1894', 'content': 'It is customary to speak of "the march of civilisation." As regards West Africa the phrase has a significance altogether too slow. Even "leaps and bounds" does not adequately represent the rate of progress, which can only be measured by the pace of the steam engine. That too, will presently be distanced by the onward move of events which has already brought West Africa to the threshold of such an advanced outpost of civilisation as technical education. This is a sign of progress the more remarkable when it is remembered that at a not very remote period the principal instruments of civilisation in Africa were reputed to be rum and gunpowder. But the schoolmaster, chiefly through the medium of the missionary societies, has long been abroad in Africa. Light on the subject is derived from The Lagos Weekly Record, which recently, in commenting on the possibilities of the Yoruba country, as indicated in the Governor's report, remarked that "The time was at hand when the civilised Natives, now appearing to flourish in the settlement, will demand outlets for their energies, and new sources of livelihood; when in order to succeed, or even to live, they will be obliged to join the great army of aboriginal producers, or ally themselves to the foreign consumers, or be crushed between the two."

The necessities thus summarised are recognised both by the Government and by the missionary societies, and the former is devising the establishment of an institution for training youths in various handicrafts. At present, it is stated, the whole of the coast is dependent for mechanics upon the protégés of the Basel Mission and repatriates from the Brazils. The extension of the work of technical education is encouraged by the success that has attended the efforts of the Basel missionaries, thanks to whom "the Gold Coast is now the principal source whence good coopers, carpenters, blacksmiths, and wheelwrights can be obtained, and the skilled mechanics of Accra are in great demand all over the West Coast from Sierra Leone to the Congo." The fact that there is scope in the Colony, as well as at other points along the West Coast, for almost any number of skilled mechanics, certainly favours the enterprise now under the consideration of the Government, and this scope for technical skill cannot fail to be greatly broadened as the interior is increasingly opened up. The practical steps which are being taken in the direction of equipping African youths in the most modern of civilised fashions for the struggle for existence on their own soil may be briefly summed up. The Bishop of Sierra Leone, assisted by Canon Taylor Smith, will, during their present visit to England, make an effort to raise £2,000 for the erection at Freetown of a technical school for the education of young Africans: whilst Captain Denton, during his residence in England on leave, will give attention to the details of the proposed Government scheme.'}, {'id': 6483, 'article_title': '"Technical Education" in West Africa', 'full_section_title': '"Technical Education" in West Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1894#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_08_1894', 'content': 'While recognising the substantial advantages which must accrue to West African colonies by a judicious effort at technical education, it is not a little amusing to note the strain in which our contemporary apologises for West Africa being behind the times in the matter under discussion. "We used to think some time ago," it observes, "that technical training of our young men would produce a superfluity of talent in one direction, exceeding the demand. But when we come to think of the openings to be made in the near future in the interior for all the technical skill we shall then be able to command, it is impossible to exaggerate the importance of the enterprise now under the consideration of the Government. Besides, all experience shows that men properly trained in technical knowledge receive such a mental stretch and development that they are capable of entering, if necessary, upon other pursuits with intelligence and success." By way of illustration the fact is recalled that "John Bunyan was a tinker, Benjamin Franklin a printer; Hugh Miller a stonemason, and several great men in England in recent times have risen from the work bench to Parliament." So Young Africa is encouraged to believe that it will not spoil itself for any higher flights of civilisation and culture in the near future by allowing itself to be schooled for the present in merely mechanical arts. —Liverpool Daily Courier.'}, {'id': 6495, 'article_title': 'MR. J. P. HAASTRUPP, OF LAGOS.', 'full_section_title': 'MR. J. P. HAASTRUPP, OF LAGOS.', 'last_edit_date': '09-01-1894', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1894#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_09_1894', 'content': 'behaviour; but that does not mend matters much. Even if Ogedemgbe had given offence to the Lagos Government, they ought to have gone to the King and Council of Ilessa for redress, instead of arresting him on its own account."

As to the future of himself and his country, our worthy friend remembers he is in God's hands, and trusts that strength and wisdom may be given him to be fit for the great duties he may be called upon to perform in the natural course of events. He would seek the protection of England, and look to a British Resident to advise him, and especially to see that English subjects in his country behave well, and that if his subjects behave ill, their offences are punished. Above all, he says, I would encourage education, believing that the enlightenment of children's minds is the only way to root out superstition and crime, and to train up men and women to do their duty to themselves and each other. It is by education and the spread of intelligence, that you can put an end to polygamy and domestic slavery, and tribal feud and the other effects of ignorance that prevail in Africa. "If the English will help us to work out our own salvation, under God's blessing, it will be for their good as well as ours.'}]
